abstractText: The eternally non-Markovian Pauli channel is an example of a unital channel characterized by a negative decay rate for all time t > 0. Here we consider the problem of constructing an analogous non-unital channel, and show in particular that a d-dimensional generalized amplitude damping (GAD) channel cannot be eternally non-Markovian when the non-Markovianity originates solely from the non-unital part of the channel. We study specific ramifications of this result for qubit GAD. Specifically, we construct a quasi-eternally non-Markovian qubit GAD channel, characterized by a time t∗ > 0, such that the channel is non-Markovian only and for all time t > t∗. We further point out that our negative result for the qudit GAD channel, namely the impossibility of the eternal non-Markovian property, does not hold for a general qubit or higher-dimensional non-unital channel.

sections.heading: On the eternal non-Markovianity of non-unital quantum channels
sections.text:
Shrikant Utagi,1, ∗ Subhashish Banerjee,2, † and R. Srikanth3, ‡ 1Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India.
2Indian Institute of Technology Jodhpur, Jodhpur - 342037, India. 3Theoretical Sciences Division, Poornaprajna Institute
of Scientific Research, Bengaluru - 562164, India.
The eternally non-Markovian Pauli channel is an example of a unital channel characterized by a negative decay rate for all time t > 0. Here we consider the problem of constructing an analogous non-unital channel, and show in particular that a d-dimensional generalized amplitude damping (GAD) channel cannot be eternally non-Markovian when the non-Markovianity originates solely from the non-unital part of the channel. We study specific ramifications of this result for qubit GAD. Specifically, we construct a quasi-eternally non-Markovian qubit GAD channel, characterized by a time t∗ > 0, such that the channel is non-Markovian only and for all time t > t∗. We further point out that our negative result for the qudit GAD channel, namely the impossibility of the eternal non-Markovian property, does not hold for a general qubit or higher-dimensional non-unital channel.
I. INTRODUCTION
Open quantum systems is the study of the dynamics of the system of interest taking into account the effect of its ambient environment and an important aspect of this is the study of nonMarkovian (NM) dynamics [1–3], which has gained increasing attention recently in the quantum information theory community [4–10]. A number of definitions of non-Markovianity have been proposed namely, based on distinguishability [11], completely positive (CP-) divisibility, fidelity [12], negativity of the decay rate [13, 14], quantum temporal correlations [15, 16] and a more general definition based on deviation from semigroup structure [17], to name a few.
The notion of quantum non-Markovianity has always been debated, see for instance Ref. [7, 18–22]. Its revived interest is due to the advent of newer experiments with finer engineered baths, which highlight the fact that there exists no universal definition or criterion which faithfully characterizes, detects or measures quantum non-Markovianity. Most of the developments focused on the two-time dynamical maps and the divisibility criterion based on the two-time correlation functions in determining the Markovian status of open system dynamics, See Ref. [4–6]. A stronger notion of quantum Markovianity has recently been developed, that is based on an operational point of view [18–23] and eschews the use of the concept of the not-completely positive (NCP) intermediate map. Moreover, this approach meets the status of necessity and sufficiency of characterizing non-Markovianity when multi-time correlations correlations are taken into account. For the present purpose of this work, we restrict ourselves to the divisibility criteria based on the two-time correlations and two-time dynamical map formalism. In particular, we will be concerned with the eternal CP-indivisibility and P-indivisibility of channels whose non-Markovianity originates solely from the non-unital part, which we definite shortly.

Now, we are in a position to define the concept of divisibility of a map.
A CPTP qubit map E(t2, t0) (a qubit quantum channel) is said to be CP-divisible if for arbitrary intermediate time t1 it can be written as
E(t2, t0) = E(t2, t1)E(t1, t0), (2)
such that E(t2, t1) is a CP-map. The Choi-Jamiolkowski matrix [29] or B-matrix [30] for a map E(t2, t1) is given by
χ = (E(t2, t1) ⊗ I)[|Ψ⟩⟨Ψ|], (3)
where |Ψ⟩ = 1√2 (|00⟩ + |11⟩) is a maximally entangled state. When χ is negative, the channel E(t2, t0) is CP-indivisible, in the sense that it is a CPTP map that cannot be written as composition of CP maps as in Eq. (2). For bijective maps, the above requirement is equivalent to the following condition for CP-divisibility
d dt ∥[Id+1 ⊗ E(t)](ρ1 − ρ2)∥1 ≤ 0 (4)
being always satisfied for given any two density operators ρ1 and ρ2 in the space of bounded operators of the bipartite system B(Hd+1 ⊗ Hd) [31]. Here, ∥A∥1 = Tr( √ A†A) is the trace norm of an operator A. The channel E(t2, t0) satisfies P-divisibility if
d dt ∥E(t)[ρ1 − ρ2]∥1 ≤ 0 (5)
for any initial pair of states ρ1 and ρ2. Note that when the condition (5) breaks down, the intermediate map E(t2, t1) would no longer be positive, in the sense that it outputs a negative state. However, the full map E(t2, t0) is still CPTP but no longer P-divisible.

For Pauli channels, it is straightforward to arrive at Eq. (7) from Eq. (6) from the so-called H-matrix method [32, 33]. This example was later shown to arise under the mixing of two Pauli semigroups [34], providing an example of the fact that the space of CP-divisible Pauli channels is not convex [35]. This is an instance in which the criterion Eq. (5) for witnessing nonMarkovianity fails [14]. Interestingly, in [36] the authors studied whole families of eternal and quasi-eternal unital channels. ENM evolution arising from a convex combination of Markovian semigroups has recently been extended to the context of generalized Pauli channels in dimension k [37], where it is shown that (d − 1)2 out of d2 − 1 decay rates can be always negative.
The examples of ENM evolution given above all have two broad restrictions: (1) the concept of non-Markovianity here refers to CP-indivisibility, and not the stronger condition of P-indivisibility; (2) they consider only unital– specifically Pauli– channels. Here we wish to address the 2nd of these points. So far as known to us, there are only a few works addressing similar questions about non-unital channels. Here we undertake to do this, studying in detail the generalized amplitude damping (GAD) channels [2, 38].
Before embarking on our results, we present a notion of non-unital non-Markovianity as below. Any d-dimensional dynamical map may be given a matrix representation as E(t) → F (t) as

Definition 1 When non-Markovianity originates solely from the non-unital part, i.e., from τ (t), then we call it non-unital non-Markovianity and such a channel will be called purely non-unital non-Markovian channel.
Given this notion, we ask: is eternal non-unital non-Markovianity, as per the Definition (1), possible? We answer this in the negative for a class of non-unital channels. However, we will later show that for a class of phase-covariant channels and higher dimensional non-unital channels, eternal non-Markovianity is still possible, nonetheless such a non-Markovianity originates from the unital part of the channel.
This is work is organized as follows. In Section II we introduce a d-level GAD channel for d-dimensional systems and show that it cannot be eternally non-Markovian. In Section III, we further provide rigorous proof for the case of qubit GAD channel and show that the utmost one can achieve in this direction is a quasi-eternal non-Markovian GAD channel, of which we explicitly construct a qubit example. In Section IV, we point out that this negative result does not extend to non-unital channels in general, by providing an example of a non-unital channel that is ENM. We present our conclusions in Section V.

sections.heading: II. GENERALIZED AMPLITUDE DAMPING AND THE IMPOSSIBILITY OF ETERNAL NON-MARKOVIANITY
A. Qudit generalized amplitude damping
sections.text:
A well-known exemplar of a qubit non-unital channel is the GAD channel [2, 39]. In this work, generalizing the well-known d-level amplitude damping channel [40, 41], we introduce a d-level GAD channel EG for d-dimensional systems given by
EG = d−1∑ l=0 plEl, (12)
where pl is the probability with which the lth damping channel El acts on a d-dimensional system, along with the constraint that ∑ l pl = 1. Here El damps an arbitrary input state
ρ to the state |l⟩⟨l| with probability λ, and is defined by the Kraus representation El[ρ] =∑d−1 j=0 El,jρE † l,j
with the Kraus operators in terms of damping parameter λ as
El,l = |l⟩⟨l| + √ 1 − λ d−1∑ k=0 k ̸=l |k⟩⟨k| ; El,j = √ λ |l⟩⟨j| , (l ̸= j). (13)
A key point about the damping channels is that they have a unique fixed point F. For the amplitude damping channels El it is |l⟩⟨l|, and for the higher-dimensional GAD channel the fixed point is F ≡ ∑d−1 l=0 pl |l⟩⟨l|.
We have the following result.
5 Theorem 1 A non-unital GAD channel in any finite dimension d that is eternally CPindivisible in the non-unital part is impossible.
Proof: In the Markovian case, any initial state is driven monotonically towards the fixed point F, fulfilling Eq. (4) for all pair of states ρ1 and ρ2. If this CP-divisibility condition is violated at time t = 0, then there is a pair of states such that
d dt ∥[I ⊗ E(t)](ρ1 − ρ2)∥t=0 > 0. (14)
With the idea of maximizing the l.h.s in Eq. (14), we let ρ2 ≡ I ⊗ F and ρ1 ≡ I ⊗ ρS for an arbitrary system state ρS .
It can be shown that the action of the GAD channel Eq. (12) is described by
E(ρS)[t] = λ(t)F + {(1 − λ(t))F + √ 1 − λ(t)G}, (15)
where G is a matrix consisting only of off-diagonal terms dependent on the initial state. In the Markovian case, λ(t) increases monotonically from 0 to 1, and thus E(ρS)[t] evolves monotonically from the initial state to F. Note that this corresponds manifestly to non-unital behavior. In specific, E(F) = F at all times t, as required by the definition of a fixed point. We have from Eq. (15) that
∥E(ρS)[t] − F∥ = √ 1 − λ(t)∥G∥. (16)
Given that GAD constitutes a CP map, λ(t) ≥ 0 such that λ(0) = 0. Thus, we have that λ̇|t=0 ≥ 0. Then it follows from Eq. (16) that
d dt ∥E(ρS) − F∥t=0 ≤ 0, (17)
contrary to the implication of Eq. (14). □ In the following, the above result for the general case of qudits will be elucidated in the case of qubits.

IV. NON-UNITAL CHANNELS AND ETERNAL NON-MARKOVIANITY
The impossibility of ENMity of GAD provokes the question of whether this is generic for all qubit non-unital channels. Yet, a simple example suffices to show that this is not the case. Consider the non-unital channel generated by linearly combining the generators the above Pauli ENM channel and an amplitude damping (AD) channel. An example would be:
L(ρ) = [σXρσX − ρ] + [σY ρσY − ρ] − tanh(t)[σZρσZ − ρ]
+ γ(t)[σ−ρσ+ − 1 2{σ+σ−, ρ}], (32)
where γ(t) is arbitrary decoherence rate for an AD channel. The action of a unital channel leaves the identity operator unchanged, whence ρ̇ = Lunital(ρ) = 0 if ρ ∝ I. The non-unitality of the channel described in Eq. (32) follows, noting that L(I) ̸= 0. Employing the notation σ∓ ≡ 12 (σX ± iσY ), the above equation can be rewritten as
L(ρ) = ∑ j,k dj,k(σjρσk − 1 2{σkσj , ρ}), (33)

Ref. [45] points out an example of non-unital ENM channel belonging to the class of phase covariant qubit channels Epc, which are characterized by the property that eiEσz Epc[ρ]e−iEσz = Epc[eiEσz ρe−iEσz ]. The generator has the form Lpc ≡ γz(t)[σzρσz − ρ] + γ(t)[σ+ρσ− − 1 2 {σ−σ+, ρ}] + γ(t)[σ−ρσ+ − 1 2 {σ+σ−, ρ}], where it can be arranged so that γz < 0 for all t > 0 [45]. Incidentally, this model was also considered in Ref. [46] in a different context.
Although this settles the question regarding the existence of a purely non-unital ENM channel, this also leads to the observation that in the above mentioned instances, the channel is not purely non-unital, in that the generator in either case can be expressed as a mixture that includes a unital component. Moreover, it is this unital component that introduces the ENM-ity.
It could be asked whether this no-go result is specific to two-level systems. It is straightforward to show that these results hold in general to arbitrary finite dimensions, by taking a trivial extension of the qubit dynamics, by embedding the qubit in two dimensions and padding the additional dimensions with an identity operation. This point can be manifestly illustrated by considering another simple way to produce an example of non-unital ENM-ity, namely by combining the Pauli ENM channel with non-unital channels taking recourse to a higher dimensional space. Consider a ququart (4-level quantum system), wherein the “lower” two-dimensional subspace, spanned by |0⟩ and |1⟩, is subject to the above Pauli ENM channel, whilst its “higher” two-dimensional subspace, spanned by |2⟩ and |3⟩, is subject to an AD or GAD channel. In other words, the two parts of the ququart are locally decohered, so that the sum of diagonals is preserved within each subspace and there are no cross-terms in the noise operator across the two subspaces (e.g., |1⟩ ⟨2|, etc.). This is mathematically captured by requiring that the generator for the ququart evolution is given by:

These diverse examples examined in the Section suggest that a purely non-unital channel (i.e., one lacking any unital component) is impossible. Although we have only studied the qubit case, we conjecture that it is true for non-unital channels in arbitrary finite dimensions.
V. CONCLUSIONS
The ENM Pauli channel [14] presented the rather counter-intuitive idea of a quantum noisy channel that is recoherent for all t > 0. Here we address the question of the possibility of a non-unital channel that is ENM, and show that it is impossible for the well-known class of GAD channels of qubits.
We point out that this impossibility of eternal non-Markovianity does not hold for arbitrary non-unital channels. Specifically, as evident from examples discussed above, one can construct an ENM non-unital channel by a linear combination of the generators of an ENM unital channel and an arbitrary non-unital one. However, we conjecture that for a non-unital channel with no such unital component (in the above sense) to be ENM, is impossible.
A consequence of our above negative result is that the best that a qubit GAD channel can approach the ENM property is to be non-Markovian for all times above a non-zero threshold time t∗, i.e., strictly t∗ > 0. By way of illustration, we provided an example of a “quasi-ENM” GAD channel, which is non-Markovian for all time t ≥ t∗ > 0.
